Violation_Type: Failure to meet physical presence requirement for citizenship
Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying the physical presence test to determine residency
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 876 days over a four-year period, failing to accumulate the required 1,095 days of residence
Court_Ruling: No error in applying the physical presence test; appeal dismissed
Defendant_Behavior: Applied statutory interpretation consistent with the Citizenship Act
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient residency days as per statutory requirement
Legal_Standard: Quantitative (physical presence) and qualitative (centralized mode of existence) tests for residency
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal based on the record before the Citizenship Judge, governed by Federal Courts Rules
Review_Standard: Statutory interpretation and application of law
Evidence_Used: Record of applicant's absences and presence in Canada
Application_Basis: Physical presence test applied as correct interpretation of residency requirement
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of applicant's presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Applicant must be physically present in Canada for at least 1,095 days within four years
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant failed to meet the 1,095-day physical presence requirement
Decisional_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Cause_Description: Applicant challenged the Citizenship Judge's decision for rejecting his citizenship application due to insufficient residency days
Evidence_Handling: Reviewed based on existing record without new evidence
Evidence_Assessment: Absence of 876 days confirmed; physical presence test correctly applied
Decision_Rationale: The physical presence test is a valid and correct interpretation of the statutory residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c)
Legal_Standard_Applied: Physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
